channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Apatzingán Journal: Under Gang’s Rule, a Mexican City Loses Hope in the State
item.description: Apatzingán has been under the control of a gang called the Knights Templar, with little interference from state or federal authority.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop was burned in Apatzingán, Mexico. Many thought the attack was a message from the gang the Knights Templar.

item.title: Climate Aids in Study Face Big Obstacles
item.description: The latest draft report by United Nations climate experts cites technologies that are still in their infancy, with few projects operating around the world.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: News Analysis: In South Sudan, Some Lessons of Rwanda Learned, Others Revisited
item.description: The United Nations has taken greater steps to protect civilians from the conflict, and while approval for reinforcements has come quickly, the troops and equipment have not.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Civilians seeking protection stacked their belongings outside the gate of the United Nations compound in Bentiu, South Sudan.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 3rd Arrest in Rape of Danish Tourist
item.description: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a Danish tourist and said they were still seeking five other men.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Lede: Video From U.N. Panel Grilling Vatican Officials on Abuse of Children
item.description: At a United Nations meeting in Geneva, committee members questioned Vatican officials about sexual abuse cases by the clergy involving children.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: U.N. Panel Questions Vatican on Handling of Clergy Sexual Abuse
item.description: Officials’ lengthy interrogation had long been awaited by abuse victims.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Silvano Tomasi, the Vatican's representative to the United Nations, left, spoke to Msgr. Charles J. Scicluna, the Vatican's former chief sex crimes prosecutor, in Geneva on Thursday.

item.title: Italian Port Chosen as Transfer Point for Syrian Chemicals
item.description: The port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, was picked because of its facilities for transferring cargo ship-to-ship.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Lede: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
item.description: Egypt said journalists from Al Jazeera English detained on Dec. 29 had “confessed” to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, but their network denied the claim.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: The Lede: Free Markets, Infidelity and the President of France
item.description: Among President François Hollande’s proposed changes – while dealing with revelations of his supposed infidelity with an actress – was a pledge to cut public spending and slash the payroll taxes for business.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: François Hollande, the president of France, after voting in the April 22, 2012, election that brought him to power. Seated next to him is his partner, Valérie Trierweiler.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Police Reveal Discovery of More Explosives in Envoy’s Residence
item.description: The police said the explosives, found in the residence of the Palestinian ambassador after a safe there exploded, killing him, were undergoing ballistic tests.
item.dc:creator: By HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: Guinea Worm Said to Infect Few in 2013
item.description: Only 148 cases of Guinea worm disease, which is on the brink of extinction, were found in the world in 2013, the Carter Center announced.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Let’s Stop All the Insults, North Korea Says
item.description: A proposal by North Korea to South Korea calls for an end to all the cross-border invective both sides have hurled at each other for decades.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: World’s Biggest Annual Human Migration Begins in China
item.description: For 40 days, hundreds of millions of Chinese will hit the roads, rails and airways to get home and back over the Lunar New Year festival.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A traveler carries his luggage at a railway station in Beijing at the beginning of the holiday rush.

item.title: The Lede: A.P. Cameraman Detained in Egypt After His Images Appear on Al Jazeera
item.description: A cameraman covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was arrested on Wednesday while transmitting live video from a polling place in Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.N. Says Lag in Confronting Climate Woes Will Be Costly
item.description: Another 15 years of failure by nations to limit carbon emissions could make the situation virtually impossible to solve with current technologies, according to a draft United Nations report.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: A coal yard worker's stained hand in Hefei, China, in 2007. Gains in renewable energy are being swamped by rising emissions from fossil fuels in fast-growing countries like China, according to a new report on climate change.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 16
item.description: Motorists driving through thick fog on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Motorists driving with their headlights on through thick fog on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Tensions Between Afghanistan and U.S. Increase as Airstrike Kills Civilians
item.description: A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two villagers, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: U.N. Says Executions in Syria By Rebels May Be War Crimes
item.description: Mass executions of civilians and of fighters who were no longer participating in hostilities were reported in the northern cities of Aleppo, Idlib and Raqqa.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: India Ink: In Assam, an Idea Whose Time Has Not Yet Come
item.description: The state’s chief minister made headlines earlier this month when he said his constituents would move their clocks ahead of the rest of the country, but it looks like he spoke too soon.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Men sitting around a fire at 4:30 p.m. after sunset in Hattigarh, in Assam, on Dec. 29, 2013.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Hollande Affair Rankles the British Press
item.description: When François Hollande refused to follow the British (and American) playbook when dealing with his recent scandal, outrage among British journalists was palpable.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France kept the discussion focused on policy at a press conference Tuesday, irritating some of the British press.

item.title: Trial Opens Into Killing of Lebanese Premier, Absent the Accused
item.description: At a special tribunal in The Hague, the prosecution said a suicide bomber created a “man-made hell” in the 2005 assassination in the Lebanese capital.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: An international tribunal opened hearings into the killing of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, on Thursday in a courtroom in the Netherlands.

item.title: India Ink: A Village Takes Small Steps Toward Reconciliation After Muzaffarnagar Riots
item.description: Economic necessity has prompted talks in Fugana, Uttar Pradesh, between the Hindu Jats and the Muslim residents who fled after the violence that erupted in September.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Hajiman Ali, 55, at Jogiya Khera village on Jan 8. He refuses to return to his village in Fugana.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Airpocalypse’ Smog Hits Beijing at Dangerous Levels
item.description: Pollution levels in China’s capital hit the upper level of the measurement scale, a dangerous development for Beijing residents.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Outspoken Uighur Scholar Detained in Beijing
item.description: Ilham Tohti, an economist, has been critical of Chinese policies in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, and said economic discrimination fueled dissatisfaction among Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking minority group.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In Greece, Elites Are Starting to Feel the Pain
item.description: Prosecutors, working independently of politicians, are pursuing corruption cases against a widening pool of current and former officials and members of the business elite.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
